title: Business Registration Checklist
description: Step-by-step guide to legally registering your side hustle.

sections.heading: 1. Choose Your Business Structure
sections.text: Decide whether your side hustle should be a sole proprietorship, LLC, or corporation. Each option has different **tax, liability, and paperwork** implications.

sections.heading: 2. Register with the State
sections.text: File the required formation documents with your state. This usually means Articles of Organization (LLC) or Articles of Incorporation (Corp). Fees range from $50–$500 depending on your state.

sections.heading: 3. Obtain an EIN
sections.text: An **Employer Identification Number (EIN)** is like a Social Security Number for your business. You can get one free in minutes from the IRS website. Even if you don’t plan to hire, an EIN is useful for opening a bank account.

sections.heading: 4. Apply for Business Licenses
sections.text: Depending on your industry, you may need permits (food handling, home occupation, sales tax ID). Check your city and state’s requirements.

sections.heading: 5. Open a Business Bank Account
sections.text: Keep your finances separate. Many banks offer free business checking for LLCs. This is crucial for protecting your liability.

title: Startup Budget Template
description: A practical framework to estimate costs, track expenses, and plan for profitability.

sections.heading: 1. Estimate Startup Costs
sections.text: List **everything needed before you launch**: equipment, website, licenses, initial marketing. Be realistic — most new entrepreneurs underestimate these.

sections.heading: 2. Track Monthly Expenses
sections.text: Break down fixed (rent, subscriptions) and variable (supplies, ads) expenses. This helps you identify your burn rate (how much cash you spend monthly).

sections.heading: 3. Forecast Revenue
sections.text: Estimate conservative, expected, and optimistic revenue scenarios. This gives you guardrails for decision-making.

sections.heading: 4. Cash Flow Cushion
sections.text: Always plan for at least **3–6 months of runway**. Many businesses fail not because of profitability but because they run out of cash.

sections.heading: Pro Tip
sections.text: Consider using a simple tool like [Wave Accounting](https://www.waveapps.com/) or [Google Sheets](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/) instead of expensive software until you scale.

title: Side Hustle Starter Kit
description: Everything you need to launch your first side hustle quickly.

sections.heading: 1. Find Your Idea
sections.text: Start with your **skills, passions, and available time**. Ask yourself: What do people already ask me for help with? What do I enjoy that could be monetized?

sections.heading: 2. Validate Fast
sections.text: Don’t build in a vacuum. Test demand with a simple landing page, pre-sales, or a small pilot. Your goal is to confirm people will pay, not just that they like the idea.

sections.heading: 3. Set Up Tools
sections.text:
Use free or low-cost tools to stay lean:
- Website → [Carrd](https://carrd.co/)
- Design → [Canva](https://www.canva.com/)
- Automation → [Zapier](https://zapier.com/)
- Payments → [Stripe](https://stripe.com/)

sections.heading: 4. Time Management
sections.text: Dedicate **consistent weekly hours**. Even 5 focused hours beats 20 scattered ones. Protect your hustle time like any other commitment.

sections.heading: 5. Build Your First Customer Base
sections.text: Leverage personal networks, online communities (Reddit, Discord, LinkedIn), and offer beta discounts in exchange for testimonials.
